entry.title: Kmail2 Evolution
entry.content:
Semantic desktop and KMail2 - why, oh why?

I liked the kdepim/korganizer approach for its integration in the KDE Desktop, it's feature rich, configurable, integrated with all the KDE eye-candy. In my opinion: if Linux ever goes Desktop, then KDE would be my bet.

I enjoyed then in particular the features available with KMail2, be it the support for the ubiquitous use of HTML-eMails (creating eMails in claws-mail being the feature I really missed there), easily managing different identities, KDE-integrated support of PGP and S/MIME, and the really great eye-candy, up to support of "X-Faces".

So far, so good.

There's a feature coming with the PIM tools: the infamous semantic desktop nepomuk using the virtuoso backend, the dependency on either mysql or sqlite. First concerns have been about its performance - well, "640 kB ought to be enough for anybody." is past, my current PC copes well with KDE requirements.
Performancewise.
Maybe the preference of sqlite over mysql did good.

Accidentally, incidentally KMail2 - with kdm sessions staying open until kernel or KDE-upgrade - freezed from time to time: new eMails were available for getting read but not for getting deleted. Imap server is accessed in parallel by other MUA's, but this can not really be the cause.
Recipe for rectification: re-create the imap account. A nice occasion to consider if folders should be treated locally or server-side --- and that's the point where I made the worse experience of getting my home 100% filled by the nepomuk data at $HOME/.kde4/share/apps/nepomuk/repository/main/data/virtuosobackend and $HOME/.local/share/akonadi.

Okay, disk layout is flexible with lvextend and resize2fs, but then I was really baffled by the sizes.
Retrospecting the backups for the "normal" condition which I did not pay attention before:

  • IMAP storage: 1.4 G
  • $HOME/.kde4/share/apps/nepomuk/repository/main/data/virtuosobackend: 850 M
  • $HOME/.local/share/akonadi: 694 M

I'm kind of wondering why (, oh why?) it is "normal" to have the amount of meta-data necessary for the semantic backend surpass the amount of original data.

So, to bring that to an end I switched to Evolution (well, at least it does what I need), and after having removed the imap account in akonadi and having cleaned the backends the partition regained some room for further KDE "improvements":

  • $HOME/.kde4/share/apps/nepomuk/repository/main/data/virtuosobackend: 13 M
  • $HOME/.local/share/akonadi: 1.4 M

For indexing files, nepomuk allows to include/exclude directories. It might help to see a selective approach for mail storage as well?

entry.title: Fail2ban Asterisk
entry.content:
Attempts to abuse asterisk

Recently asterisks messages started to fill at my private installation with (denied) attempts to dial-out, eg.

[May 11 03:26:34] NOTICE[13665][C-000109c5] chan_sip.c: Call from '' (an.ip.addr.ess:port) to extension '00972597636927' rejected because extension not found in context 'local-context'.
[May 11 03:26:34] NOTICE[13665][C-000109c6] chan_sip.c: Call from '' (an.ip.addr.ess:port) to extension '000972597636927' rejected because extension not found in context 'local-context'.
[May 11 03:26:35] NOTICE[13665][C-000109c7] chan_sip.c: Call from '' (an.ip.addr.ess:port) to extension '900972597636927' rejected because extension not found in context 'local-context'.
[May 11 03:49:53] NOTICE[13665][C-000109c8] chan_sip.c: Call from '' (an.ip.addr.ess:port) to extension '0000972597614173' rejected because extension not found in context 'local-context'.

Fail2ban needed an additional failregex to match

failregex = (...)
    ^(%(__prefix_line)s|\[\]\s*)%(log_prefix)s Call from .*?\(<HOST>(:\d+)?\) to extension \S+ rejected because extension not found in context \S+

NB.: eMails created by fail2ban did not show up with a correct Date:-header. Changing in /etc/fail2ban/action.d/*: 

Date: `LC_TIME=C date -u +"%%a, %%d %%h %%Y %%T +0000"`

to 

Date: `LC_TIME=C date -R`

solved that.

entry.title: Hotmail Postfix
entry.content:
TLSv1 issue with hotmail, smtp-mail.outlook.com

When using the hotmail-server to deliver eMails, authenticating at that server with postfix/SASL results in the error logged in the mail syslogfile:

... postfix/smtp[22318]: Untrusted TLS connection established to smtp-mail.outlook.com[65.55.162.200]:587: TLSv1 with cipher DES-CBC3-SHA (168/168 bits)
... postfix/smtp[22318]: warning: TLS library problem: 22318:error:1408F10B:SSL routines:SSL3_GET_RECORD:wrong version number:s3_pkt.c:337:

Debugging with openssl s_client confirmed, at least with some of Hotmails servers:

openssl s_client -starttls smtp -connect smtp-mail.outlook.com:587 -crlf
...
ehlo some.name
...
250-AUTH LOGIN PLAIN XOAUTH2
250 OK
140393594386088:error:1408F10B:SSL routines:SSL3_GET_RECORD:wrong version number:s3_pkt.c:337:

All okay with SSLv3 only, openssl s_client -starttls smtp -connect smtp-mail.outlook.com:587 -crlf -ssl3

enforce SSLv3 with Hotmail

With the framework in main.cf

smtp_sasl_password_maps = hash:/etc/postfix/sasl_passwd
sender_dependent_relayhost_maps = hash:/etc/postfix/sender_relay
sender_dependent_default_transport_maps = hash:/etc/postfix/sender_dependent_transport

master.cf requires a specific transport defined:

smtpsaslssl         unix    -       -       n       -       -       smtp
        -o smtp_tls_mandatory_protocols=!SSLv2,!TLSv1
        -o smtp_tls_protocols=!SSLv2,!TLSv1

use the specific transport, /etc/postfix/sender_dependent_transport

<hotmail_address>   smtpsaslssl:

together with the entry in sasl_passwd:

<hotmail_address>   <hotmail_address>:<hotmail_password>

and the entry in sender_relay:

<hotmail_address>   [smtp-mail.outlook.com]:587

... works for me

... postfix/smtp[3325]: Untrusted TLS connection established to smtp-mail.outlook.com[65.55.96.11]:25: SSLv3 with cipher RC4-MD5 (128/128 bits)

entry.title: Gen2 Installnotes
entry.content:
Gen2 installation

Notes on the Gentoo-Installation I did on my Dell 3440 Netbook, based on the Gentoo Installation Handbook

In my humble opinion Windows applications are ubiquitous still, so I wanted to install Gentoo additional to the pre-installed Windows flavor. For mobiles it should be a matter of course to have at least private data encrypted --- installing Gentoo on an encrypted disk is my lazy choice.

I'm not a friend of a "one partition fits it all" approach, mount-flags disallowing eg. devices on the /home-partition are a very basic means of increasing security - LVM the choice to be flexible. EXT4 allows online reduction and seems to be a path towards BTRFS --- else my experiences with JFS were very good.

With the chosen crypt-parameters here's a brief summary of the initial steps:

setting up the encrypted physical volume

# SHRINK Windows, using the Windows tool
# define a physical partition, later for /boot --- sda2
# define one partition covering "the rest" --- sda6
fdisk /dev/sda
# luksFormat partition
cryptsetup -y --cipher twofish-cbc-essiv:sha256 --key-size 256 luksFormat /dev/sda6
# make partition available
cryptsetup luksOpen /dev/sda6 root
#

prepare logical volumes

# defining the physical volume on luks container
pvcreate /dev/mapper/root
# define the volume group and the logical volumes
lvcreate -L8GB -n swap vg
lvcreate -L5GB -n root vg
lvcreate -L15GB -n usr vg
lvcreate -L5GB -n var vg
lvcreate -L10GB -n home vg
lvcreate -L1.5GB -n opt vg
# ensure boot-manager will find the kernel+initrd
# set aside a physical partition containing the /boot-data
mkfs.ext2 /dev/sda5

assemble prepared partitions into the /mnt/gentoo - mountpoint used for installation

# create & use swap
mkswap /dev/vg/swap
swapon /dev/vg/swap
for i in root usr var home opt; do mkfs.ext4 /dev/vg/$i; done
mount /dev/vg/root /mnt/gentoo/
mkdir /mnt/gentoo/boot
mount /dev/sda5 /mnt/gentoo/boot
# spot the udev'ified name of the network-interface and bring it to life
net-setup enp7s0
mkdir /mnt/gentoo/{home,opt,var,usr}
for i in home opt usr var; do mount /dev/vg/$i /mnt/gentoo/$i; done
cd /mnt/gentoo/
# continue with https://www.gentoo.org/doc/en/handbook/handbook-amd64.xml
links http://www.gentoo.org/main/en/mirrors.xml
tar xvjpf stage3-amd64-20130822.tar.bz2
vi /mnt/gentoo/etc/portage/make.conf
mirrorselect -i -r -o >> /mnt/gentoo/etc/portage/make.conf
cp -L /etc/resolv.conf /mnt/gentoo/etc/
vi /mnt/gentoo/etc/resolv.conf
mount -t proc non /mnt/gentoo/
mount -t proc none /mnt/gentoo/proc/
mount --rbind /sys /mnt/gentoo/sys
mount --rbind /dev /mnt/gentoo/dev
chroot /mnt/gentoo /bin/bash

mental notes...

With an encrypted root-fs the kernel created at last step of the installation from media must contain the chosen encryption cipher and algo at kernel .config > Cryptographic API Also, make sure the kernel command line refers to the designated crypt_root and real_root.

For getting the german keyboard on console-windows right:

/etc/conf.d/keymaps: keymap="de-latin1"
/etc/conf.d/consolefont: consolefont="lat9w-16"

For getting the german keyboard with Xorg-server:

/etc/X11/xorg.conf:
Section "InputClass"
    Identifier "evdev keyboard catchall"
    MatchIsKeyboard "on"
    MatchDevicePath "/dev/input/event*"
    Option "xkb_layout" "de"
    Driver "evdev"
EndSection

Using the Haswell integrated graphics required

kernel .config:
Device Drivers > Grphics support > Intel 8xx [...]
  Enable modesetting [...] must be enabled

Using the integrated BlueTooth chip required ath3k

kernel.config:
Networking support > Bluetooth subsystem support > Bluetooth device drivers
(don't forget to emerge linux-firmware)
